title: Your First Command
description: Welcome to Linux! Let's start with the basics. Type the 'pwd' command to see your current directory.
hint: pwd stands for 'print working directory'. Just type pwd and press Enter.
successMessage: Great! You've displayed your current directory. You're in /home/user.

title: Listing Files
description: Now let's see what files are in your current directory. Use the 'ls' command to list them.
hint: Type 'ls' to see the files and folders in your current location.
successMessage: Excellent! You can see the documents and projects folders.

title: Show Hidden Files
description: Some files are hidden (they start with a dot). Use 'ls -a' to see all files including hidden ones.
successMessage: Perfect! Now you can see the hidden .bashrc file too.

title: Navigate to Documents
description: Let's move into the documents folder. Use the 'cd' command followed by 'documents'.
hint: cd stands for 'change directory'. Type: cd documents
successMessage: Well done! You've navigated into the documents folder.

title: Read a File
description: There's a file called 'readme.txt' here. Use the 'cat' command to read its contents.
hint: cat displays file contents. Type: cat readme.txt
successMessage: Great job! You've read your first file in Linux.

title: Go Back
description: Navigate back to the parent directory using 'cd ..'
hint: The '..' means parent directory. Type: cd ..

title: Create a Directory
description: Create a new directory called 'practice' using the mkdir command.
hint: mkdir stands for 'make directory'. Type: mkdir practice
successMessage: Excellent! You've created your first directory.

title: Create a File
description: Create an empty file called 'test.txt' using the touch command.
hint: The touch command creates empty files. Type: touch test.txt
successMessage: Great! You've created a new file.

title: Display Text
description: Use the echo command to display 'Hello Linux' on the screen.
hint: Echo repeats what you type. Try: echo Hello Linux
successMessage: Perfect! Echo is useful for displaying text and creating file contents.

title: Who Are You?
description: Find out your username using the 'whoami' command.
hint: Just type 'whoami' to see your username.

title: Show the Date
description: Display the current date and time using the 'date' command.
hint: Simply type 'date' to see the current date and time.
successMessage: Well done! The date command is useful for timestamps.

title: Environment Variables
description: Display your HOME environment variable using 'echo $HOME'.
hint: Environment variables start with $. Type: echo $HOME
successMessage: Excellent! Environment variables store system configuration.

title: Clear the Screen
description: The terminal is getting crowded. Use the 'clear' command to clean it up.
hint: Just type 'clear' to clear the terminal screen.
successMessage: Nice and clean! The clear command helps keep your workspace tidy.

title: Copy a File
description: Copy test.txt to test_backup.txt using the cp command.
hint: cp stands for copy. Format: cp source destination
successMessage: Great! You've created a backup of your file.

title: List with Details
description: Use 'ls -l' to see detailed information about files.
hint: The -l flag shows long format with permissions, size, and dates.
successMessage: Excellent! You can now see file permissions, sizes, and modification dates.
